modules.title: Portfolio Risk and Return: Part I

concepts.title: Risk-Return Tradeoff
concepts.desc: Higher expected return requires accepting higher risk. Historical data: stocks > bonds > T-bills in return and risk.

concepts.title: Utility Theory
concepts.desc: U = E(R) - ¬ΩAœÉ¬≤. Risk-averse investors (A>0) require compensation for bearing risk. Indifference curves slope upward.

concepts.title: Efficient Frontier
concepts.desc: Set of portfolios offering maximum return for each level of risk. Rational investors choose portfolios ON the frontier.

concepts.title: Minimum Variance Portfolio
concepts.desc: Portfolio with lowest possible risk. Starting point of the efficient frontier.

concepts.title: Capital Allocation Line (CAL)
concepts.desc: Line from risk-free rate tangent to efficient frontier. Slope = Sharpe ratio. Optimal risky portfolio at tangent point.

concepts.title: Two-Fund Separation
concepts.desc: All investors hold the same optimal risky portfolio; they differ only in allocation between it and the risk-free asset.

formulas.name: Utility Function
formulas.where: A = risk aversion coefficient (A>0 for risk-averse)

formulas.name: CAL Equation
formulas.where: Slope = Sharpe ratio of optimal portfolio

formulas.name: Sharpe Ratio
formulas.where: Excess return per unit of total risk

decisions.question: How does risk aversion affect portfolio choice?
use: More risk-averse (higher A): more allocation to risk-free asset, less to risky portfolio
Less risk-averse (lower A): more in risky portfolio, may use leverage
avoid: Assuming all investors want the same portfolio ‚Äî risk preferences differ

pitfalls: The efficient frontier is curved ‚Äî adding the risk-free asset creates a straight line (CAL)
Diversification reduces risk but cannot eliminate systematic/market risk
Sharpe ratio uses TOTAL risk (œÉ), not just systematic risk (Œ≤)

questions.question: The Sharpe ratio measures:
options: Return per unit of systematic risk
Return per unit of total risk
questions.explanation: Sharpe = (Rp - Rf)/œÉp. It measures excess return per unit of total risk (standard deviation).

questions.question: According to two-fund separation, all investors:
options: Hold the same portfolio of risky assets
Do not invest in the risk-free asset
questions.explanation: Two-fund separation: all investors hold the same optimal risky portfolio (tangent portfolio) and differ only in how much they allocate to it vs. the risk-free asset.

questions.question: A risk-averse investor has a risk aversion coefficient (A) that is:
questions.explanation: Risk-averse: A > 0 (requires higher return for more risk). Risk-neutral: A = 0. Risk-seeking: A < 0.

decisions.question: Which performance measure to use?
use: Sharpe: for well-diversified portfolios (total risk matters)
Treynor: for portfolios that are part of a larger diversified portfolio (Œ≤ matters)
Jensen‚Äôs Alpha: for measuring active manager skill
avoid: Sharpe for poorly diversified portfolios (total risk includes diversifiable risk)
Treynor when portfolio is the investor‚Äôs entire holdings

questions.question: R<sub>f</sub>=2%, Œ≤=1.2, Market return=9%. CAPM expected return:
A stock plots above the Security Market Line (SML). This means the stock is:
questions.explanation: Above the SML means expected return > required return (per CAPM). The stock offers more return than needed for its risk, so it's undervalued.

questions.question: Jensen's alpha is positive when:
options: The portfolio return exceeds the risk-free rate
The portfolio return exceeds the CAPM-predicted return
questions.explanation: Œ± = actual return - CAPM expected return. Positive alpha means the manager generated excess risk-adjusted returns.

questions.question: The Treynor ratio is most appropriate for evaluating:
options: A portfolio that represents the investor's entire wealth
A well-diversified portfolio that is part of a larger portfolio
questions.explanation: Treynor uses beta (systematic risk only), which is appropriate when the portfolio is part of a larger diversified portfolio where unsystematic risk is eliminated.

concepts.title: IPS (Investment Policy Statement)
concepts.desc: Document governing the investment process. Includes: return objectives, risk tolerance, constraints (LTTLU).

concepts.title: IPS Constraints (LTTLU)
concepts.desc: Liquidity needs, Time horizon, Tax considerations, Legal/regulatory, Unique circumstances.

concepts.title: Types of Investors
concepts.desc: Individual (life-cycle), Pension funds (DB: long-term, defined liability; DC: participant-directed), Endowments, Insurance.

concepts.title: Strategic Asset Allocation
concepts.desc: Long-term target weights based on IPS. Rebalanced periodically. Determines majority of portfolio return.

concepts.title: Behavioral Biases
concepts.desc: Loss aversion: pain of loss > pleasure of gain. Overconfidence: excessive trading. Herding: following the crowd.

decisions.question: How to set return objectives?
use: Required return: minimum needed to meet obligations
Desired return: what the investor wants (may exceed required)
Both must consider inflation, taxes, fees
avoid: Setting unrealistic return targets that require excessive risk

pitfalls: Asset allocation is the most important determinant of portfolio returns (not security selection)
Longer time horizon generally allows for MORE risk (not less)
Tax-deferred accounts: prefer high-return assets (tax-inefficient assets like bonds)
Behavioral biases can cause systematic decision errors even for professional investors

questions.question: The IPS constraint "LTTLU" does NOT include:
questions.explanation: LTTLU = Liquidity, Time horizon, Tax, Legal/regulatory, Unique circumstances. Leverage is not one of the five constraints.

questions.question: The most important determinant of long-term portfolio returns is:
questions.explanation: Studies show that strategic asset allocation explains approximately 90% of the variation in portfolio returns over time.

questions.question: Loss aversion refers to the tendency for investors to:
options: Feel the pain of losses more than the pleasure of equivalent gains
questions.explanation: Loss aversion (Kahneman & Tversky): the disutility of a loss is about twice the utility of an equivalent gain. This can lead to holding losers too long and selling winners too soon.
